Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Coding in R, working with data, essential statistics principles.
Basics of stats and R.

How to work in R at an introductory level. The depth of R knowledge required going into the course is essentially zero and much of the course is centered around developing that baseline knowledge while simultaneously teaching key econometric/statistical principles.
Learned R and basic statistics.
I learned many different kinds of statistical analysis methods, and learned how to use R to perform them.
I think this is an integral course to take for econ majors and a good introduction to statistics and working with data.
I learned a lot of basic stat concepts and how to use R.
Metrics, applications to economics
The first half of the class is mostly statistics, and the second half is the econometrics part, eg. different ways of establishing causality in economic data without doing randomized experiments.
Learned about nuances/more advanced forms of regression such as Diff-in-Diff, discontinuities, and Instrumental Variables for Randomized Experiments.
A great introduction into how statistics and data science can be used to make informed and below the surface analysis and observations.

In this course, I learned how to effectively use different kinds of data to answer economic and social inquiries in the world and also how to evaluate the findings of a data set that was presented to me.  The five main concepts that we covered in class were: probability, statistics, linear regression, causality, and prediction.

Picture this: Davies Auditorium, Monday Morning at 9am. While the vast majority of Yale College and Economics 117 lies asleep, you force yourself out of a beautiful slumber, beating the laziness and lethargy plaguing all Monday mornings. Proudly, you walk into class and realize you are one of 12 students in a 130 person class. This is a typical Economics 117 class. Shockingly, the material is actually useful and necessary in this class (using R, basic statistics, applications to the real world). Yet the obstacle of both making it to class and staying awake while staring at jejune powerpoints with glazed eyes proved to be too much for me and 90% of my peers. Perhaps 5-10 students in this class possessed a deep love for econometrics and I can guarantee none came. The rest realized you can aptly learn the material simply by glancing over the powerpoints on your own time. You will not want to take this class, but you must for the major (Econ, EP&E etc.)
I learned the data analysis program R and some statistical properties
Quite hard but good in understanding how to use R
Basic stats mostly
This class taught me so much about statistical programming, how to make a research design with binary variables, how to evaluate econometrics and studies from other economists.
I learned how to use R and how to apply statistical knowledge to different economic problems.

basic understanding of econometric concepts and techniques, learning to code in R (a popular data analysis program)
topics include: probability, random variables/expected values, conditional expectations, the normal distribution, sample vs population, variance and covariance, Central Limit Theorem, confidence intervals and hypothesis testing, univariate/multivariate regression, prediction and causation, regression techniques like instrumental variables and difference-in-difference analyses
Introduction to statistical methods, improved my skills in R
Rules and functions on probability, statistical tests, different regressions (linear or otherwise) and how to implement them, etc.

I learned how to apply the economics topics I learned in ECON 115 during the fall to statistical application. We worked with real-world data to solve statistical problems, in addition to completing R code.
I had no prior experience in stats or R, so I gained foundational skills in both. I'd also say I learned a lot basic data analysis and interpretation skills, so I have much more data literacy.
I learned how to build prediction models based on given sets of data, understand causality between variables, and work with the statistical computing program R.
I learned about the intersection of statistics and economics.

I developed a statistical mindset for looking at problems.  In particular, because most factors in causal situations cannot be pinpointed to be exact causes, it is helpful to think about failing to reject something as a predictor or causal agent, and rejecting a factor rather than choosing to accept a factor.  Really good intro to statistics class and it's nice to think that I can now somewhat use R in thinking about and modeling big data.
Introduction to Econometrics
Good introduction to basic R in an applied context. You get to accelerate through a number of interesting statistical treatments of data as well.
Introductory skills to econometrics.
I learned basic statistics in this course.
how to code and view lots of data and make large conclusions from it
One of the best courses offered at Yale. Prof. Humphries is an amazing professor and actually cares about his students.

This class offered me a strong introduction to statistics, data analysis, and basic R programming. We covered topics like hypothesis testing and probability, and mostly applied them to real-life data sets and examples. As a History of Art major, it gave me a new, basic framework for thinking about data and being able to approach it in articles, empirical papers, etc.
I learned about important econometrics concepts
Econometrics, basic statistics, and coding in R
I learned basic statistics, r programming, and approaches to econometric modeling.

I learned the basics of  r, and how to implement statistics within it in order to analyze data. Through this skill, I also learned how to analyze data in order to get answers or important statistics in economic models.

Learned lots of statistics and some R. Very good intro course. The problem sets are long but very manageable because lots of time is allowed in between due dates. Learned how to evaluate data. Tests are hard but interesting
Statistics, regressions, nothing else

One reason I wanted to take this course was to get a sense of what econometrics actually is, and I think this course did give me a decent idea of what econometrics is through example problems and using real data and papers.
The time of the class does not induce doing learning a lot in lecture since it's at 9am. Also the professor makes simple concepts extremely hard to understand by making them complex.
The Psets were a good combination of theoretical and emirical work, although they could have pushed me more in terms of R skills.
More in class examples with R

I think the first portion of the course (introducing probability, expected value, etc.) could definitely be made shorter, because the material in the later portions of course is more complicated yet we only have minimal time to cover each new topic.

Strength: great teacher and TA's, very accessible, piazza was great for questions with quick response times 
Good usage of R
The class does a great job of introducing statistics, R, and econometrics. The grading is fair and the workload is reasonable.

Strengths: A lot of resources for help - peer tutors, TA office hours
Weakness: It could be helpful to figure out a smoother start to the semester. Trying to learn statistics and R at the beginning could be a lot.
I wish there were more examples rather than a lot of theory slides.

Thought content was not arranged in an interesting way. 
Felt like R was not super well integrated, but compared to other classes that use R, Im not sure if its any worse than the others
More focus on working through problems

Strengths: Cool material, great professor, easy-to-follow pace.
Weaknesses: A little too slow at times, 9 am....

The first half was pretty much just an intro to probability. I wish this had been more clear, because I thought the course would be far more focused on the 2nd half of the year stuff (regressions, models, expeirments, etc) than basic probability and intro stats.

Strengths: course content, applicability and the ability to start using new techniques and skills you develop almost immediately.
Weaknesses: Powerpoint slides were too lengthy, psets started to get weird at the end, with not difficult, but confusing questions beyond material covered in class.

I thought that this was a very solid course overall.  I think one way that this course could be improved is by settling the amount of R code that was used in the class.  While the homework and lectures were very R heavy, the exams (which were the majority of the grade) really were not.  I think it would have been really useful to see less R in lecture and more conceptual topics, and use the problem sets as a space for students to really delve into R and get more experience there.

Strength: N/A
Weakness: Tough curve, low level of engagement, terrible time and place (Monday 9am)
The homework was very engaging and helpful to understand the material.
The class is quite fast and sometimes difficult to keep up with
It simply isn't super engaging material.  Problem sets are also too easy compared to exams.
The strengths of the course is that every lesson makes you learn so much, however, the study is so condensed that it is inevitably exhausting to keep track.

The early morning lectures were difficult to follow and were fairly fast-paced. Lecture slides were also very long. The group-style problem sets however and the organization of those assignments and quizzes were nicely spaced throughout the semester. There could be more midterm and final preparation.

Strengths: well-organized overall:  topics are in modules (probability, descriptive/inferential statistics, regression, etc.); class structure is essentially divided into econometric concepts and R programming; grading into exams, psets (comprising conceptual and R coding sections), quizzes (and optional final project) 
Weaknesses: not anything worth bring up
The TA office hours could have benefitted from larger rooms, and the sections were not as helpful as anticipated.

Strengths: Very engaging lecture slides, easy to keep up with if a lecture is missed.

Weaknesses: Sections could be better structured to help students learn, my TF was not engaged with material so I rarely went to my assigned section. Additionally, the time of the class to start the week made it slightly inaccessible, especially during midterms.

The strengths of the course is definitely the breakdown of grades and assignments. The occasional open-note quizzes were great for keeping track of how well you understood material. I also think the grade breakdowns were pretty generous overall, especially being able to drop one of the PSET grades. I don't think anyone should go into this course worrying about their grade; if you're willing to put in a normal amount of work, you will be fine.

Weaknesses is definitely the weekly labs/sections. They're not mandatory, which is great, because every time I attend one, I feel like i got very little out of it. It was a good opportunity to ask any clarifying questions on material, but most of the time you could just look at the lab/section notes online and gain just as much in less time than the usual section. I also think sections could have benefited from more focus on conceptual material as opposed to R.

That said, lecture itself was pretty solid and definitely useful. Professor Humphries really did a great job with the slides, especially after he starting focusing more on the conceptual side of things and provided more detailed slides after midterm feedback. Prof. Humphries himself was also very enthusiastic about the material, so lecture was never really dry or boring (what was tough was the 9am time).

This course is very well-organized and therefore, relatively easy to follow despite that the content could be challenging at times. It could improve, however, by incorporating more problem solving in lecture time.
The primary weakness of the course was that it was at 9am, so there was not a lot of engagement during the lecture. The slides were also quite repetitive and could have been more clear.
My only complaint with the course was the fact it was at 9am.  The course could be improved by starting later than 9am.
Lectures could be condensed. A lot of useful information though.

The strengths were useful applicable skills using real world case studies to teach them.

The main weakness was the fact that there was an emphasis on R programming and R-related skills during problem sets, but an overwhelming bias toward applying pure statistics on the exam. While this is not the worst thing ever, it would have been nice for R skills to be both tested and to some extent rewarded in an exam setting.

Professor Humphries is an amazing lecturer and professor. He cares a lot about his students. However, I think the final exam should be tailored to fit the content more. I believe students were expecting an exam that is similar in length and difficulty as what we were presented with in practice exams from previous years. We were also under the impression that R codes that we have not used previously would not be tested. Other than the final, this course was great!
This course is good because the material is understandable and useful. However, many of the concepts are made excessively complicated by slides and explanations that are far too theoretical.
strengths lied in applicability of problem sets while weaknesses lied in lack of helpful sections and tediousness in lectures
I think sections should be mandatory considering the large class size.

This course focuses on important, applicable skills (like basic coding and hypothesis testing), rather than unnecessary memorization or complex calculus. It is well-structured for student learning, with constant assignments to ensure that students keep up with the material without adding too much unnecessary stress. In the future, I think that the midterm exam should be more difficult (to differentiate students more on the standard Econ department curve), and that lecture time should not be dedicated to R-coding (except for a basic introduction to the program at the outset of the course).
The lecture notes are very detailed which is extremely helpful with such dense course content
Strengths were the pset, lecture slides, and support from lecturers, TAs and peer tutors. Weaknesses were lecture style and sections.

I had no prior experience with r before entering this class, and I think the course was very good at introducing this language to the students. The problem sets were always very helpful and a good tool to study what we had learnt the prior weeks. However, I feel that the lecture itself could have been more engaging and clear with what was been taught.

The amount of access to receive help in the course is really great. Professor Humphries works hard on Piazza and Canvas to make resources available to students. The amount of time to spend with information is really great. My only thing I would change is to add one more midterm to provide more opportunities to improve grades in the class.

Course was all stats, thought it was boring. Had to take it for econ, would have made it more relevant to doing own research. Probably learned the right material, I just didn't follow all the time and exams were hard. Was not a life-changing course :(

I think one of the major weaknesses of this class was that we did not learn the theory behind the statistical tests we learned. Without knowing the inner workings of the statistical tools we are using, we are just memorizing formulas and their requirements. Another weakness of this course is the emphasis on R. While its a useful language to know, it doesn't make sense that we were tested on knowing R code, since R code is incredibly easy to learn about online. Further, knowing R does not mean one understands the econometrics, and knowing all the econometric tools does not mean we know R.
Strengths: Prof. Humphries does a good job of explaining things. I also really liked the fact that he posted slides on Canvas, as it served as a good reference.
Take econ 135/136 instead. Trust me.
Don't recommend it. Only take it if you have to. Well-structured slides, but dry lecture.
Only if you need it for the major

Since its essentially a required course for the econ major I guess many of you will have to take it, although I would be prepared for the challenge of a 9 am class which is slightly dependent on you going to lecture if you are going in with no prior knowledge.
Yes!
Yes, I believe it would help students who are interested in reading economic papers, since it introduces many of the basic analytical deas that economists use in their work.
Yes, great teacher, great TAs, good material, has improved much more since the first 117; take it with John he's a great teacher (although 9ams are hard to make)
I think this is a great into to econometrics, but if you haven't taken a stats class before be ready to put a little more time into it than your classmates.

I would recommend to anyone within the major, or anyone from outside of the major who has an interest in programming and/or statistics and/or how either of those subjects can be used to study social issues.
Yeah. But if you take it, its probably because you had to

Yes! I think econometrics is really useful, and ECON 117 is totally manageable whether or not you have economics or statistics background. Plus, John is so eager to help any student and is in general a very energetic lecturer, so I really liked being in his class.

I think they covered too much intro Stats/Probability for this class. For example, we learned PDFs and CDF for continuous and discrete functions, but those hardly came up at all outside of the lectures in which they were introduced. If I had not had prior knowledge of them, I would have been very confused and failed to see their connection to other information.
Yes, if you are looking for an alternative to YData, a great QR or a test to see if you like the computational aspects of the economics major this is a great course.

This course is very tough.  While there are definitely useful skills acquired from taking it, it is not for the faint of heart.  I would recommend it only if you are an econ major (which it is a requirement for) or are very interested in stats/econ.
It's painful but I seriously doubt anyone would take this unless it's a requirement for their major  so yes, take it. Not that bad just extremely painful.
Yes if you want to learn more about econometrics and get a good foundation
You probably need it for your major.  But the PSETS and tests don't seem super well thought out.

I highly recommend this course because data analysis and econometrics is fundamental for economics, political science, and more subjects in the humanities than one may think. If you have never programmed before, R actually provided a really good start and learning base.
Yes, it is very cool and useful to learn stats through an economic perspective while also learning simple coding using R.

Yes, I think this course gives you a great introduction to econometrics and R.  Both are tools that are essential in other economics/data science courses as well as in any profession that deals with data (basically all of them).
Yes. Great instruction and design.
It is not the most organized course in which to learn R, or to explore basic statistics.
Yes, I would recommend this course. It will be easy for you to do well, especially if you have a knack for stats and not necessarily Econ or math.

I mean you're probably taking it as a rec, but this is definitely a manageable course. I came in with no prior R or any stats experience whatsoever, and still did very well. I think you just have to be willing to go to office hours for some of the PSETs and it is so important to find another group of students to work with. Fortunately, Prof. Humphries helps with finding study groups, which is really nice of him.

The class itself also greatly benefits from all the real world examples. It is a highly practical class in which you learn by applying what you learn to real life scenarios and using real data.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. This course is a great means to establishing a fundamental understanding of how data analysis works. The content is thought-provoking but at the same time, not overwhelming. Therefore, it is welcoming to students of all backgrounds in statistics.
I would recommend this course to other econ majors because its required, but if you want to learn about statistics and are not an econ major, I would recommend a different statistics class.
Yes, assuming they don't put it at 9am again.
If you have to take it for your major, take it. Otherwise, I would not.
If you need it
I would - the TFs and professor are really good and these are important modern skills.
Yes, a good introduction to econometrics.
I would only recommend this course to econ majors. It's not particularly interesting and is not that easy.
only those following the economics major or else other coding focused classes can be better
Yes. Great intro to econometrics

Yes, I would recommend this course if you are looking for an introduction to data analysis in a relatively low-stress setting. As someone who is not an Economics major, has a weaker math  background, and has no coding experience, I felt completely comfortable in this class. If you put in the necessary effort, you will likely grasp the material.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in learning important statistics concepts and R language.
Yes
Yes, I think ECON 117 is a great introduction to an increasingly important facet of economics.

Yes, I think this course was very interesting and well organized. There was a diverse array of real life problems studied in class, and analyzing them was always entertaining; it makes you feel like a real economist.  Also, for students new to R, it's a good introduction to the language.

I would recommend this course to students with no statistics background as it is a very simple, interesting start to learning the subject. I would recommend it to more than just econ majors because it is a great way to learn two subjects without having to have a very hard class on top.

Only if you need to take it for major, or love stats, but then there are probably better classes, this one was frightening. Felt like I learned it but final proved me wrong, most of that was timing though. Overall, not a fun time, 0/11 :(

I would not recommend this course to a student who has any interest in the statistical theory of econometrics. I would only recommend this course to people who need it for their major or people who want an easy course that gives them some practice with R and basic statistical analysis, and who are not interested in the math behind these tools.
